Watching all of the staff standing around yakking away just made us roll our eyes. Madisonians are suckers for this kind of wanna-be urban hipster crap and it is just embarrassing. Lah de fucking dah, suckers.  Afterwards, we went across the street to The Caribou, were greeted by a friendly bartender and served promptly.

Items Selected: Coffee Egg Cream - Cold Brew Dogwood Coffee, Cream, Honey, Lemon, Egg White Cold Brew Dogwood Coffee Goat Sausage with Crispy Baguette, Mustard, and Olives Galantine of Poussin stuffed with cabbage and almonds - Mustard Greens, Pickles, and Olives Caramelized Carrot Cavatelli and Roasted Carrots with Carrot Top Pesto and Parmigiano Reggiano Malt Ice Cream with Crushed Potato Chips, Crystalized Kumquats, White Chocolate Crisp, and Hot Fudge  Ostensibly a sequel to the oft-lamented Underground Kitchen with a meat heavy menu featuring daily specials from Madison's heralded Underground Butcher it was for a few pre-dinner bites that I sat down at a tiny two-top at Forequarter and although my pending reservation at L'Etoile would indeed limit my order I'd be hard pressed to say which experience was more impressive.  Without doubt a trendy space, heavily wooded with tiled ceilings and taxidermy, it was just after 5:30 that I entered the dimly lit dining room and with the bar already buzzing as several tables dined on charcuterie it would not be long before a menu was in hand and selections were made, the service proving exemplary in both keeping my water glass full and presenting each plate with ample descriptions of sourcing as well as technique.  Unfortunately beginning the night on a sour note, literally, as lemon ruined an otherwise delicious sounding egg cream it was with the beverage stricken from the bill and replaced by cold brew that the meal was reset and although perhaps a bizarre 'pairing' for charcuterie I'm happy to say the bitter contrasts surprisingly worked - a board of boldly spiced goat sausage first perfuming my palate with smoky notes only to be followed by tender poultry imbued with earthy aromatics and extremely subtle brine.  Realizing coffee would overwhelm my main course and thus cleansing my palate with pickles plus tiny olives that packed some seriously salinity it was onward to a vegetarian-friendly bowl of pasta that my meal progressed and with hues of purple, orange, and green in full effect the flavor was even more impressive than the visual display - each tender noodle rife with natural sweetness while butter-roasted Purple Knights and decisive pesto melded into a nutty, rich sauce.  At this point unable - or at least unwilling - to eschew dessert it was between a plate of cookies or a housemade sundae that I was left to decide and deferring to my waitress as to which she preferred I opted for the later, fond childhood memories of the movie-snack "Whopper" brought forth with every bite.

Astonishing place!  Every time we go we are surprised by new dishes made with fresh seasonal ingredients with a wonderful combination of flavors, textures and wit.  This is our favorite restaurant in the Midwest (beating shallow show spots like Alinea to a pulp) and rivals places like Tilth in Seattle for our top spot overall.

Well, right off the get go let me say I'd like to make this a 4.5 star review but since that's not an option I have to go with four stars. There were a couple small but notable things that could have been better and made this slightly less than 'as good as it gets'.   I made reservations for two for Forequarter on Valentine's Day. Given the small size of the restaurant and the holiday we were happy to get any reservations (even if they were for 5pm). We arrived a bit early and were directed to the Caribou bar across the street for a pre-dinner cocktail. When we walked back across the street at 5 several tables were already seated and we were shown to a small table for two. Our coats were taken to be hung and we looked over an impressive bar menu and a dinner menu that was especially exciting. We ordered quite a few things so we could try different options and we ran across some really amazing things, as well as a few that could have been a bit better.   Drinks: Elmer T Lee + house ginger beer. This was the first thing I ordered and it was mildly disappointing. Elmer T is a nice bourbon and it was completely lost in the drink. The ginger beer was quite good but the drink as a whole was unimpressive. My wife enjoyed a glass of Sauvignon Blanc that was solid but somewhat unremarkable.   Charcuterie plate: We got the three meat option with lots of pickled veg on the side. This was a really tasty way to begin the meal. We ordered the lomo, coppa, and sopprasata. Before the board arrived at our table we were informed that the last serving of sopprasata had already been ordered and asked if a replacement of dried goat salami was okay. All the pickled veg was delicious (although the purple cauliflower was very heavy on the anise). The lomo was silky, the coppa perfectly salty, the two together PERFECT! We pretty much cleared the entire board, including the full grain and Dijon style mustards. What a way to start a meal!   Appetizers: Green chorizo and butter beans. Wow, this is an INCREDIBLY tasty dish. The gravy was rich and deep and perfectly complimented the smooth texture of the beans. The chorizo is bursting with amazing flavors; herbal, spicy, meaty, fatty, all at the same time. Every component of the dish perfectly complimented the others. This was exceptional!   Fried mushrooms with black garlic. WHOA! This is ASTOUNDING! I'd read a ton about it elsewhere on Yelp, so I won't belabor the point here, but this is a phenomenally delicious dish! There's umami galore in this dish and I would guess anchovy paste is in there somewhere. Whatever it is and however they make it it's DELICIOUS! This is a must have!  Turnip tart. This one was a slight miss, but could be corrected pretty easily to be quite good. The pastry was excellent; light, flaky, delicious, and both the onions and cheese on top were a plus. The turnips on the other hand seemed to have NO seasoning whatsoever. The texture was nice I can see where the dish was headed, but the execution of the turnips left something to be desired. Even a bit of salt would have made the turnips more 'turnip'y' and the dish as a whole far better.  Entrees: Lamb roulade with root veg pave and pancetta aioli. This was a an excellent lamb dish! By appearance alone I might have guessed the lamb was slightly overdone, but the taste and texture proved otherwise. The lamb was tender and succulent with nary a trace of gaminess. In general I'm not much of a aioli fan, but in this dish it added a TON of flavor and a richness that was hugely desirable. The pave was amazing! On the plate it looked a bit like a brick, but the taste and texture paired perfectly with the lamb. The pave added a crunch that hugely benefited the dish as a whole. the way it was plated allowed a bit of the jus from the lamb to soak into the bottom of the pave and every bite was AMAZING! One piece of my roulade was served with a piece of twine still wrapped around it, which was a very minor detail and easily fixed. This was the only detail less than spectacular about the whole dish.   Black garlic glazed chicken with roasted carrots. This was a good dish that just didn't quite click for me. The black garlic glaze had a great depth of flavor but was a little on the sweet side for me. The chicken is served more rare than many folks will be used to seeing it, but that allows it to be hugely moist. I like the flavor of chicken when it's cooked a little more thoroughly, but that's just me. The carrots were very tasty and added a nice texture contrast to the chicken but for me this entree couldn't hold a candle to the lamb. By no means was it bad, it was just over shadowed.  Dessert: blood orange cake with pink peppercorn ice cream. The cake was great but the ice cream was ASTOUNDING! We both loved the way it tingled in the mouth and put a perfect cap on a really solid meal.   All in all a great meal with a few, minor missteps. I could certainly see returning to Forequarter in the future. Well worth the $!

This place was recommended to my by the B&B at which I was staying. I arrived a little after 6pm, and it was not busy at all. By the time I left, it was full of people and good energy!  I started with a New Glarus Two Women (only in Wisconsin... and Chicago) and a special cheese platter with a Wisconsin bleu cheese, jam, bread, nuts, and a slice of honeycomb. Shamazing. For my main dish, I decided to go with the carrot cavatelli, roasted carrots, and carrot top pesto. You'd think it'd be carrot overload, but no. It was a great blend of flavors with only a little carrot taste to it all! I finished of with their cookie platter and a walnut liquor with coffee and cream.  Worth every calorie! When you're going to indulge, it should be a place like this: great atmosphere, great ingredients, minimal processing, and straight up deliciousness. So glad I followed the recommendation. I hope you follow mine!

The hubby and I enjoyed ourselves this morning, we sampled a number of their brunch items. I started with their house made bloody Mary and he started with their dogwood French press coffee. I found the bloody Mary to be spicy, and I have an easily identifiable horseradish flavor, however I did not have any chunks of texture and that was a nice detail. My husband was impressed with the accoutrements served alongside his coffee; the natural cane sugar and cream, both in tini mason jars. We ordered the daily muffin, which was not on the menu and should never be overlooked. Inside was a perfectly cooked soft boiled egg and the muffin itself was so airy and light and fluffy that it blew both of our minds. Next, we ordered the breakfast potatoes and those were also delicious. They had a creamy sauce but we're not smothered in them, and I thought that was a great touch, and dollops of mustard seed. Lastly, for our entrées my husband ordered the cheese grits, poached eggs and brats from the underground butcher, all perfectly executed. I ordered the cured trout and the soft scrambled eggs with an herb salad; however, the entrée did not come with an herb salad (see photo). I'm now really disappointed about this but until actually creating this yelp review I hadn't noticed it. Everything we had there was incredibly delicious.

The food was good, but the waitress took a sip of my wife's drink as she was walking towards our table. My wife told her that she couldn't believe what she had just seen, and all the waitress said was that the drink was a "good choice." No apology! Nothing! Unbelievable! She didn't even offer to refund the cost of the drink, or have a new one made. We left. No tip for the waitress. No return trip planned. There has got to be something wrong with a restaurant that would employ a waitress who feels that behavior is okay.

Food:  2 stars  Drinks:  4 stars  Service:  3 stars  Ambiance:  4 stars (would be five, but the noise made hearing the server impossible)  My dining companion and I had been dying to try Forequarter for quite some time, and we finally pulled it off last night.  We both left sated, but underwhelmed.    The trout was the highlight of the meal, with the cheddar cheese plate coming in second.  My spare ribs were a huge disappointment--particularly the texture, which was tough and difficult to consume.    Service gets a few demerit points for not bringing a steak knife with spare ribs.  I know that this may seem like a common practice, but these spare ribs were extremely tough and two other diners at the bar asked for steak knives, so she should have gotten the hint by then.    Part of the trout dish was also undercooked badly--the fingerling potatoes.  That's pretty bush league in my book.  One of them was inedible it was so raw.    Cute place, great drinks, and fantastic concept--but someone needs to work on the quality of the meats and the execution in the kitchen.  If this is a "five star" place in your mind, you need to get out more, my friend.
So f@&$ing good!  That's exactly what he said in response to the $5 happy hour burger. Maybe the best burger in town in the last 25 years

Had three meals here and none were bad. Very intimate (tables close to one another) and they don't take reservations - but I guess that's part of the charm.  Menu changed every time we went so it's an adventure. The waiters' suggestions were always reliable. We usually order about 4 dishes and share. Has always worked out.

Definitely in my top 10 in Madison. I like to come here with a group of five or six to share four or five small plates and one or two larger ones. Favorites: fried shiitake, and braised pork belly. Their house ginger beer's pretty nice, too.  It is a bit small on the inside, so be prepared to come early/late, or wait a bit.

Great restaurant with easily the best cocktails in Madison. Cute atmosphere. There is often a very long wait, though, so it pays to show up early or be prepared to go to the bar across the street for 90 min while you wait. At the end of the day, though, it's always the first restaurant I recommend to people when they come to town.   Also, they do a killer Sunday brunch!

I had high expectations going into Forequarter and they did not disappoint. Our server was exceptionally friendly and helpful without being overbearing. Our cocktails and entrees were majestic landscapes of flavor. The portions were a little small, but we also split a couple of appetizers so we left satisfied without being too full. Great place for a date, even with sitting at the bar. I'm surprised that other people are so quick to chastise in their reviews over a single grievance. Take their emotions with a grain of salt.
Had the trout. This place blew me away. I was not expecting to find this jem and I'm glad I did. I ate at the bar and would recommend doing the same if its your first time.

Someone give this place a Michelin Star.  I went to a New American restaurant last night and was reminded of Forequarter.  The restaurant was decent, but I just kept recalling how amazing my meal was at Forequarter.  There are so many restaurants trying to be similar to Forequarter in Seattle, but they are just not successful.  I just don't know how Forequarter can improve.  It is that amazing, and it is worth a trip back to Wisconsin to relive that experience.

I'm torn. It's a solid 4, but can be 4.5. I've had an amazing meal here and I've had meals that on the one hand were interesting, but left me wanting more (and needing more to eat).  Since it's a constantly changing menu with different chefs in the kitchen it's hard to pinpoint specific dishes, but that's one of the cool things about this place is that you'll always find something new and thought provoking.   Their late night beef sandwich has consistently delivered and challenges (but not quite beats) the Tornado Rooms steak sandwich as the best late night food in Madison.

This is where I had my first carob pie/tart dessert it was yummy. The outstanding feature of this location is how creative they are with the vegetables, yes vegetables. For a meat lover I am ok with and wish there are more restaurants like this. It was a $50 dinner after splitting with 2 other gals but was a tasty and memorable eat!

I've driven this street scores of time over the years when visiting my daughters at UW, and never noticed this building.  Maybe the iconic Caribou Tavern across the street draws my eyes everytime.  But that changed with Forequarter arriving.  The mixologist behind the bar was engaging and prepared phenomenal drinks.  I tried his version of an Old Fashion and Manhattan.  Wow.  Familiar yet different and better than what I've experienced.  Watching him in action was also part of the experience.  So focused, high volume, yet all bespoke work...except for the pre-made cocktails.  I only sampled one from the tap and it was "off" that night according to the mixologist.  I still like the idea of kegging drinks and will try one next time I'm around.  I'll reserve judgement on the food until my next visit.  I enjoyed the fried chicken but I don't think it is a signature dish for them.  My wife and daughter loved their vegetarian option.  Unique selections with great ingredients for everything I saw.  There is thinking in the kitchen.  Learned later they have received some national attention.  Based on my experience they deserve yours.

My favorite restaurant in Madison for a date night or intimate meal with a friend. Best for small groups and I love eating at the bar. Awesome fresh cocktails and the food is outstanding. Always new stuff to try and can always count on a fabulous charcuterie? board when in doubt. Sooo happy I live just a walk away!

So came in on a Thursday night, 545. Wanted to sit at the bar, like we always have, to have some drinks and a few small plates but we're  asked if we had a reservation; to just sit at the bar? Isn't that what the bar is for, non-reservation, wait for a table, a few drinks, etc? Pretty disappointed that we need a reservation to eat here now. Unfortunately probably won't be back because we usually just like to hit a few spots, not commit to one place, but this was definitely one of our go-to's for great drinks and good food. Too bad, pretty disappointed.

Outstanding!!!!  The collective keeps developing new ideas and is becoming a local food mecca.  I went as a group of four just prior to Christmas and tried all but 2 items on the menu.  Their menu is concise and artfully described, but limited to about 16 items in all.  I tried everything, but my favorite part of my meal was those cheesy potatoes, sounds so Midwestern, but when they use Rush Creek Reserve .... I need not say more.  I happen to add a little extra of that cheese sauce to the braunsauger.    Day after our feast we headed to the Underground Butcher for take home memories of our meal!

Forequarter has everything I have wanted from restaurants in the genre of the local, slow food movement. It lived up to all of my dreams of taking Wisconsin cheeses, meats, and local harvests and pairing things from the delicate to the bold spectrum.  I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants to discover what is, to me, truly Wisconsin.  The food was delicious, the candles were placed well, the staff seemed real and approachable, the food came at good intervals, and the experience was casual but with a very high quality.  I could go on and on, but you need to just go try this place.

We were up and down on this place as the meal progressed, but finally came down to no. We decided to order one of the small plates as an appetizer and then two dinner plates for the main course. We started with a small plate of fried mushrooms, and they were spectacular -- shitakes fried until crispy around the edges and served in a garlic-shallot vinaigrette.   Then the main courses came. My wife ordered whitefish. The bite she shared had a distinct fishy taste, but the celeriac was perfectly cooked. Can't say I tasted the other flavors listed on the menu: katsou dashi and preserved lemon salsa verde. I sampled the broth, and what I mostly tasted was salt, same with my dish. I had the ricotta-herb dumplings. These also came with a bunch of thinly sliced shitakes, and a good thing because I had only three dumplings of about an ounce each -- and I shared half of one with my wife. My dish was marked as a "large plate," but only the serving plate could qualify as large.  This points up the main problem: portions were much too skimpy. I'm not looking for a plate that's piled high, but there should be enough food to satiate the appetite. My wife's fish portion looked like 3 to 4 ounces. If there had been a bread plate or a side of pasta, or even a few more dumplings in my dish, it would have been a satisfying meal. But there was none of that, nor enough vegetables to make up the difference. Even half an hour after we left the restaurant we were still hungry.   With a couple of cocktails, the price for two was about $72. Given the too small portions and lack of interesting flavors in most of the food, it is doubtful we'll go back especially at that price.

It had been a little while since last visit, and I was looking forward to Forequarter, but it did not make the grade this time. The wild mushroom dish was fantastic as always.  Great great great!  The cabbage wedge salad was a big miss.  Grilled lukewarm and tough cabbage with a one-note flat dressing and under-seasoned.  This salad could have really benefited from some seasoning and some kind of acid.  I contemplated asking the bartender for some lemon wedges and  salt/pepper to improve it.  That would have improved it, but I don't think it would have saved it.  The dumpling dish my wife ordered was described as a large plate. I guess if you call 3 dumplings that are approximately the size of a potsticker each a large plate then you will be fine with this.  The veg and sauce/broth with it were good.   But dumplings were not so special or laden with pricey ingredients (ricotta) that the portion should be so small.  The whitefish was good, not great.  We sat at the bar and the service was lacking.  For the first bartender that saw us, it was like we were invisible.  Lastly, and this is probably nitpicking, when I made the reservation with Resy I was asked if this was a special occasion.  I noted it was my wife's birthday, and though I wasn't looking for freebies it would be nice if they would acknowledge it.  They did not.

Forequarter. Quaint, cute, and quite exquisite.   I recommend the place for friends, coworkers, and dates. Not the best for "parents visiting town."  It is very popular, and deservedly so. We had to wait an hour for a table but we got some appetizers and drinks and waited outside. Food was delicious - tasty but not too heavy. We had 3 appetizers, the scallop carpaccio, rabbit galantine, and the potato fingerlings. All were very fresh and delicious. I particularly liked the combination of citrus and raw scallops. The potato fingerlings weren't like the typical "everything in America is fried" ordeal. It was saute'd and not overly salty.  The main dishes were also great. We had the Charcuterie board, sablefish, and salmon dishes. The fish were very juicy and well prepared with a unique flavor to the sauces. The Charcuterie board was also very diverse, my favorite being the beef liver pate. We also got desert, definitely worth it.   The reason they get 4 and not 5 (though it was a tough choice), was that the server really didn't know what he was doing... We ordered a decent bottle of wine but he had to triple check which one we wanted. He had to double check quite a few times what we ordered and his explanations on the Charcuterie board was clearly wrong (he said something was goat cheese when it was clearly meat). But, he was friendly and was clearly trying his best, so we left a 20% tip and thanked him for his efforts.  Again, great place, highly recommended, but I hope they have better-trained servers to match the quality of their food.

Food was decent but not great. I think this place is totally overrated. Service was mediocre, have to remind them twice to get the drinks or additional bread (ridiculous portions: 3 mini slices for 4 people). The place itself does not match the quality of the food. Furniture is old, layout horrible and not to what has become standard in Madison. There is no double door neither a curtain at the front door. Today's was particularly cold (around 0 F) but every time someone goes in or out you freeze to death. Price is in the range of other places in Madison, but those other places (Heritage Tavern, Nostrano, 43 North,...) are better located, better decorated and with higher level of service and food. Too noisy (because of music too loud).
The food is amazing, and yes the portions are small compared to American dishes. But as a foreigner I'm really satisfied with their changing menu and cocktails!
Hard to get reservations. But one of the best restaurants in mad town, food and service vice. You're not going to regret picking forequarter for your dinner needs.
Food and atmosphere are excellent. Try mushrooms from side dishes. Amazing! Ordered two portions.

Too hip for your own damn good! After a week in Napa sampling the amazing foods at Redd, Terra, Zuzu and Goose and the Gander I was rudely reminded of how full of themselves many of Madison's "chefs" and restaurants are...Ohhh no reservations- we're too cool for that...no you can't sit while you wait for the rest of your party...too cool for that! The charcuterie plate is the best part of the menu except for the fact there isn't enough bread or crostini...they charged $4 for more! That's 20% of the cost of the damn thing for Bread! Poached skate wing was cold and wet-not seasoned at all on a slushy chili infused pasty mash of something with raw red onions? WTF??? The chicken thigh and leg was raw...should have stuck with the apps- Brussel sprouts and beets on point- at least they bought my first drink- thimbleful of whiskey for $9 as a gesture of good will for the cold fish....to think we paid the same prices for top notch food at Chicarellos Bottega in Napa the night before reminds me why eating here is so unfulfilling!

Another great spot for a cozy date night in Madison, we recently visited on a Saturday night.  We sat at the bar for dinner which at first I was disappointed about but the bartender was outstanding.  The drinks were eloquently hand-crafted and delish.  I had the Wiscosmopolitan and the Drankin' Patna, both were equally fabulous.    We started with a sausage and cheese platter which was Point Reyes Bleu (heck yes) and a local salami which was served with spiced nuts, bread, honey, mustard and pickles...it was the perfect fun sampling appetizer!  I had the fried & poached poussin chicken with red polenta, pickled radish & spicy honey ($20) and it was outstanding...not a ton of food but this place is definitely quality over quantity which worth it!  My husband had their ribeye roast special and is still raving about it.  We will definitely be back again for a great date night downtown!

Wow!  I can't say enough about how incredible this menu is. I'm from California, and this food is just has fresh and bright as what I am used to from CA. I don't live here, but will be visiting again. I will definitely come back. Locals, come support this chef. So amazing!

The food was unique and fresh, but overpriced. The service was relatively timely. The place tends to be very crammed. On a weekend night expect to wait a while for a table. While you are waiting there isn't any place to enjoy a drink or appetizer. Also, due to the construction, it is very difficult to find parking. Considering the plethora of other excellent restaurants in Madison, I will unlikely be back anytime soon.

Forequarter is the retail, public face of the Underground Food Collective catering company. Distinctively Eastside. Low key, creative, knock-out food. This place popped up on my radar a while ago. Liz B. mentioned it the other day so the Spousal Unit and I invited a friend to go check it out. There's no sign on the building so those of you old folks that don't have smart phones should write down the address before you head out, other wise you'll walk up and down E. Johnson for a while before you find it ;-)  We three snagged the last table for four at about 6:10 on a Thursday night.  The cocktails seemed to be popular but we settled on a bottle of a nice, reasonably priced Sangiovese. When I asked about it she brought me a taste. To start we had: Ripped bread with eggplant and pork rillette and a beet (golden and red) salad. Main course was, for my companions, veal meatballs with green beans and eggplant in a light tomato sauce reduction and for me, roasted goat shank with garbanzos and cucumbers. Conversation slowed, Mmmms were said, happiness ensued. A raspberry buttermilk ice cream served with shortbread cookies dipped in chocolate ganache finished the meal. What a treat!  I've been in some fancier restaurants in Madison since moving here. They've tended to be a bit snooty and formal for my tastes.  Forequarter would fit nicely in my former hometown of Portland, OR.  Laid back, confident and creative. I will most certainly be back for more!
